result.execSummary:
This case is being appealed. If the court makes a decision in a case that a party disagrees with, the party may have the right to seek review by a higher court to determine if the trial court's decision was correct. Appeals are most often made after a trial or final decision in a case, but an appeal can also occur before a final decision.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Not eligible for Challenge Incarceration, Earned Release, Substance Abuse Program, or other prison programs. Credit of 448 days is as stipulated to by Atty. Viste and Atty. Hughes.

Conditions: Undergo evaluations and assessments as agent deems appropriate and comply with those recommendations. Pay court costs and costs of supervision. No contact with AB or her family. Defendant must register as a sex offender.

9:00 a.m. Defendant Christopher B Vine in court, in custody, with attorney Michael Hughes. Prosecuting Atty Michelle L Viste appeared for State of Wisconsin Attorney General. Court notes receipt and review of the PSI. Atty. Hughes states defense has reviewed the PSI but Def has not read all of it yet. Atty. Viste notes concerns in that fact and asks for short recess to allow Def time to finish reading the PSI. Court orders recess. 9:50, back on the record with the same appearances. Def reports that he has reviewed the entire PSI. Atty. Hughes states that Def maintains his innocence and denies allegations of previous cases and statements noted in the PSI. Victim addresses the Court. KM addresses the Court. Atty. Viste argues State's position on sentence. Atty. Hughes argues Defense' position on sentence. State has argued for consecutive sentences. Defense has argued for concurrent sentences. Def addresses the Court. 

Sentence pronounced at 11:12: 

Court follows recommendations of PSI. Count 1/Stalking - 7 1/2 years initial confinement, 5 years extended supervision; Count 2/sexual assault - 20 years initial confinement, 8 years extended supervision; Count 3/drug charge - 10 years initial confinement, 5 years extended supervision.  All three counts concurrent with each other. Credit:  448 days stipulated to by counsel.

Conditions of ES: Undergo evaluations and assessments as agent deems appropriate and comply with those recommendations. Pay cost costs and supervision fees. No contact with AB or her family.

Not eligible for programming (CIP or SAP).

Exhibits 1-3 received.

Defendant must register as sex offender.

20 days to seek postconviction relief.

Def remanded to custody of the sheriff at 11:50 a.m.
Sentencing Memorandum
and Certificate of Appearance - AMB
and Certificate of Appearance (submitted to Accts. Payable 3/8/17) - KC
and Certificate of Appearance (submitted to Accts. Payable 3/8/17) - BK
and Certificate of Appearance (submitted to Accts. Payable 3/8/17) - CNJ
and Certificate of Appearance (submitted to Accts. Payable 3/8/17) - WG
and Certificate of Appearance (submitted to Accts. Payable 3/8/17) - KM
and Certificate of Appearance (submitted to Accts. Payable 3/8/17) - MJL
Guilty all 3 counts - unanimous verdict.

1-5, offered on 2/28/17
6-14, offered on 3/1/17
15-21, offered on 3/2/17
Question from the Jury and response from the Court.

9:22 a.m.  Day 4.  Bailiffs:  Fischer and Frye.  Same party appearances as previous days.  Out of the presence of the jury, Court reviews jury instructions with counsel.  Court rules - will not instruct on lesser sexual assault instruction, requested by the Defense.  Jury in place at 9:38, Court begins reading of the jury instructions.  10:03, Atty. Viste begins closing arguments for the State.  At 11:31, Atty. Hughes begins closing arguments for the Defense.  Recess for lunch and Court's other cases calendar from 12-1:35.  1:35, Atty. Hughes resumes his closing remarks.  Atty. Viste begins State's rebuttal at 2:20.  Final instructions by the Court at 2:58.  Bailiffs sworn and alternate selected.  Deliberations begin at 3:03 p.m.

Reconvening out of the presence of the jury at 3:40, jury question noted.  Court drafts written response.  Written response given to jury.

Verdict reached; announced at 6:47 p.m.  Verdicts read by the Court:  Count 1/stalking - guilty.  Count 2/sexual assault - guilty.  Count 3/delivery of controlled substance - guilty.  Court polls the jury.  Verdicts were unanimous.  Court enters judgment, finding def guilty as charged to all three counts, according to the amended information.  Any bond previously authorized revoked.  Def remanded to custody of sheriff pending sending.  PSI ordered; to be complete by 4/20.  Court proposes sentencing 9 a.m. sentencing on April 27th.
Exhibit #19 - Not Received, Not Withdrawn, Not Denied
and Certificate of Appearance - JM (submitted to Accts. Payable 3/3/17)

Day 3.  Bailiffs: Komarek and Bradford.  Same case party appearances as previous days. At 9:02 a.m., trial resumes with testimony, cross-examination beginning by the Defense on KM.  State's redirect of KM begins at 9:25.  At 9:27, State calls witness WG.  WG sworn by the clerk and questioned on direct by Atty. Viste. At 10:07, WG cross-examined by Atty. Hughes for the Defense.  10:15, redirect by State of WG.  At 10:15, morning break.  10:35, State calls witness ML.  ML sworn by the clerk and questioned on direct by Atty. Viste.  Cross of ML by Atty. Hughes for the Defense at 11:18.  11:23, State calls witness Sgt. LM.  LM sworn by the clerk and questioned on direct by Atty. Viste.  11:30, LM cross-examined by Atty. Hughes.  Redirect of LM at 11:34.  11;35, State recalls Sgt. LM, still under oath for direct; cross by Atty. H at 11:36.  11:38, State calls witness JM.  JM sworn by the clerk and questioned on direct by Atty. Viste.  Lunch recess 12-1.  1:00, JM's testimony continues with cross by Atty. Hughes.  State's redirect of JM at 1:12. 1:16, recross.  At 1:17, State rests.  

At 1:18, Defense calls witness Det. JP.  JP sworn by the clerk and questioned on direct by Atty. Hughes.  1:44, State's cross of JP begins.  Defense's redirect of JP at 1:51.  State's recross of JP, 1:55.  At 1:56, Defense calls witness JWV. JWV sworn by the clerk and questioned on direct by Atty. Hughes.  Cross of JWV at 2:20 by Atty. Viste.  2:38, Defense' redirect of JWV.  Recross, 2:41.  2:42, recess.  Out of the presence of the jury at 2:43, Court conducts colloquy with Def re Def's decision whether/not to testify.  At 3:03, Defense calls CM.  CM sworn by the clerk and questioned on direct by Atty. Hughes.  Cross by Atty. Viste at 3:08.  Redirect by Atty. Hughes, 3:11.  Recross, 3:16.  At 3:17, Defense calls witness JV.  JV sworn by the clerk and questioned on direct by Atty. Hughes.  Cross of JV by Atty. Viste at 3:32.  Redirect of JV by Atty. Hughes, 3:49.  Recross.  Defense rests at 3:54 p.m.  

3:57 p.m., out of the presence of the jury, Court reviews jury instructions with counsel.

Day 2.  Bailiffs: Komarek and Frye.  Same party appearances.  9:03 a.m., State's direct of AB continues.  9:55, Atty. Hughes begins the Defense's cross-examination of AB.  Lunch recess at 12:00.  1:10, Defense' cross of AB continues.  Redirect by the State at 1:14.  Recross at 1:45.  At 1:54, State calls witness KC.  KC sworn by the clerk and questioned on direct by Atty. Viste.  Out of presence of jury at 2:37 p.m., during afternoon recess, Court takes stock of trial pace. 2:53, back on-the-record, Defense begins its cross-examination of KC.  2:57, State's redirect of KC begins.  At 3:00, State calls witness CW.  CW sworn by the clerk and questioned on direct by Atty. Viste.  At 3:20, Defense begins its cross of CW.  State's redirect of CW at 3:39. Recross at 3:44.  3:46, State calls witness KM.  KM sworn by the clerk and questioned on direct by Atty. Viste.  Adj. for the day at 4:30.

Day 1.  Bailiffs: Fischer and Bradford.  Security: Cejpek and Logan.  Court officer: Pilla.  Defendant Christopher B Vine in court with attorney Michael Hughes. Prosecuting Atty Michelle L Viste appeared for State of Wisconsin.  57-juror panel sworn on the record at 9 a.m. for the beginning of jury selection.  State's voir dire begins at 9:20 after Court's introductory instructions.  Defense's voir dire begins at 10:53 a.m.  Counsel exercise five strikes each.  11:34, 13 seated jurors sworn by the clerk.  Out of the presence of the jury at 11:35, sidebar notation recorded for the record. Atty. Hughes motions for mistrial.  Atty. Viste argues against the motion.  Court denies motion for mistrial.  Atty. Viste addresses the Court re motion in limine.  Lunch recess at 11:49.  12:49, back on the record.  Atty. Viste begins the State's opening remarks at 12:52. Atty. Hughes begins Defense's opening remarks at 1:24.  At 1:42, State calls witness BK.  BK sworn by the clerk and questioned on direct by Atty. Viste; at 2:06, cross-examined by Atty. Hughes; 2:12, re-direct.  2:15-2:35 recess.  2:35, State calls witness AB.  AB sworn by the clerk and questioned on direct by Atty. Viste.  Court calls the day concluded at 4:07 p.m.
State's Second Motion in Limine

Supplemental motion in limine review/discussion including witness impeachment rules.  Juror questioning of witnesses not allowed.

Attorney Andrew I. Martinez appeared by phone means for Defendant Christopher B Vine. Prosecuting Atty Michelle L Viste appeared by phone means for State of Wisconsin.  Richland County DA Jennifer Harper also present, in person, along with VW Coordinator. Jury trial scheduling - 4-day trial.  Court offers start dates of 8/16, 8/23, or 9/27, all Tuesday start dates; notes Atty. Martinez recently joined the case and has indicated he would be ready for trial in early August.  Atty. Martinez states he is not available 8/23; prefers the September date over the 8/16 date but will explore the possibility of making 8/16 work.  AAG Viste states 9/27 works for her but not sure if it will work for witnesses; it is confirmed that 8/16 works for the witnesses. Court directs counsel to inform the court/clerk by Monday, 7/11 whether the 8/16 start date will work (trial 8/16-19); in the alternative, back-up trial dates will be 9/27-30. Prosecutor to check avail. of witnesses for the September week as well.  Jury trial scheduled for August 16, 2016 at 08:30 am.  Telephone conference scheduled for July 11, 2016 at 04:00 pm.  Jury trial scheduled for September 27, 2016 at 08:30 am.

Defendant Christopher B Vine in custody and in court with attorney Andrew I. Martinez. Prosecuting Atty Michelle L Viste appeared for State of Wisconsin. Defense requests continuance, does not believe he will be prepared for jury trial due to recent appointment to case. Discussion re. time limits on speedy trial demand made.   Atty Viste will not withdraw her motion, requests DCA assign a judge so trial can commence by August 10th. Motion to continue is granted. Jury trial is cancelled for July. Scheduling to be determined. 16CF43 should also track along with this case and be reassigned.

Defendant Christopher B Vine in court, in custody, with attorney Andrew I. Martinez. Prosecuting Atty Michelle L Viste appeared for State of Wisconsin in 16CF42.  Prosecuting Atty. Jennifer Harper appeared for the State in 16CF43.  Atty. Longacre also present as the previous-appearing attorney for the def.  Court notes speedy trial demand of the State in 16CF42.  Atty. Martinez states that Atty. L today turned over the discovery in both of these matters.  Court - due to speedy trial demand, trial to be held within 90 days of May 8th; proposes July 12-15.  AAG Viste explains to Court the rationale for the State's speedy trial demand; concedes that Atty. M needs to be able to review discovery and determine if he's able to try the case those dates.  Atty. Martinez addresses the Court; states it is unlikely that defense can be ready by those dates.  Court sets 7/12 at 9 a.m. for start of the trial; directs Atty. M to review the discovery materials and advise the Court and Atty. Viste if he can be ready for those trial dates.  Court sets status conference for 8:30 a.m. June 10th via video or telephone; counsel to be present in person at the Richland County Courthouse for video or call to the Court.  Purpose of the status is for Atty. M to inform the Court as to whether/not he'll be ready to go July 12th.  If he is, June 10th will also be the date to determine what further scheduling is needed prior to trial for pre-trial matters (motions, etc).

Court formally allows Atty. Longacre to withdraw from both cases.  Atty. Martinez confirms that he has been appointed in both cases.  

DA Harper requests that the Court advises the def of 6th Amendment provisions (warning re right to counsel after discharge of counsel by the def).  Court acknowledges def's constitutional right to counsel but notes limitations provoked if def would continue to discharge counsel; such may result in forfeit of that right.

Both cases set for status 6/10 at 8:30.  DA Harper also to be present in the 16CF43 case which is only set for the 6/10 status.  Jury trial scheduled for July 12, 2016 at 09:00 am.  Status conference scheduled for June 10, 2016 at 08:30 am.

16CF42 and 16CF43 called together with appearances as follows:  Defendant Christopher B Vine in court, in custody, with attorney Adrian Wayne Longacre. Prosecuting Atty Amy Elizabeth Forehand appeared for State of Wisconsin in 16CF43.  Assistant AG Michelle Viste appeared for the State in 16CF42.  NG pleas entered to all charges in 16CF43.  Court notes 16CF42 is presently set for May trial.  Atty. L indicates he does not want 16CF43 scheduled at this time; awaiting outcome of 16CF42.  Proceeding with motion hearing in 16CF42.  ADA Forehand allowed to leave the hearing at this time as AAG Viste is prosecuting the case involved in the motion hearing - 16CF42.  

Atty. Viste motions for sealing of exhibits in 16CF42.  Viste states the rationale.  Atty. Longacre does not object to sealing.  Court grants State's request to seal the exhibits.

Continuing with remaining of the State's motions, Atty. Viste addresses the Court with argument in favor of prior acts admissibility per 904.04(2)(b).  Atty. Longacre argues against the motion.  Court notes review of jury instructions pertaining to evidence, etc.; points to Sullivan.  Court does not believe introduction of other women's statements would be unfairly prejudicial.  Motion is granted.

Court calls for motions in limine prior to trial re specific testimony that will be presented; states Defense will have opportunity to cross State's witnesses in this regard.

Motion regarding expert witness testimony of Dr. Manusa.  Argument by Atty. Longacre against said testimony.  Argument by AAG Viste in favor of allowing this expert testimony.  Court directs counsel to provide case law on this topic.

16CF42 & 16CF43 called together. Defendant Christopher B Vine in custody and in court with attorney Adrian Wayne Longacre. Prosecuting Atty Robert Kaiser appeared for State of Wisconsin for AG Viste.  Detective Pilla sworn and questioned on direct and cross. Comment by Attorney Longacre. Rebuttal by Attorney Kaiser, requests bindover. Court finds probable cause, binds def over for trial. Information filed. NG plea entered to all three charges in this matter. Defendant's
No contact whatsoever with AB, Judge Andrew Sharp, KM, WG, TF or SPW.  Additionally, no contact with any of those individuals while in custody per 940.07.
Preliminary hearing on March 16, 2016 at 01:30 pm.

Court appears by telephone from Crawford County.  All other parties as follows in the Richland County Courtroom:  Defendant Christopher B. Vine in court, in custody of the sheriff, with attorney Adrian Wayne Longacre. Prosecuting Atty Michelle L Viste appeared for State of Wisconsin in 15CF90 and 16CF42. Prosecuting Atty. Jennifer Harper appeared for the State of Wisconsin in 16CF43.  15CF90 called as motion hearing on defense' motion to modify bond.  16CF42 and 16CF43 called for initial appearance, complaints in those matters filed yesterday.

16CF42 and 16CF43 - Court conducts the initial appearances, stating the charges and informing def of the possible max. penalties.  

Court asks AGA Viste for clarification as some of the charges in 15CF90 and 16CF42 appear to be the same.  AGA Viste addresses the Court - moves for dismissal, without prejudice, of 15CF90.  No objection from the defense. 15CF90 dismissed.

Court asks prosecutors for their requests on bond. 

In 16CF42, AGA Viste makes request for 50K cash bond, providing State's rationale for the high cash request.  Vista asks for bond conditions to include "No contact with AB, Judge Sharp, KM, WG, TF, or SPW,"  Additionally, Viste asks for 940.47 finding for no contact while def in custody.

In 16CF43, DA Harper asks for 10K cash bond with condition that def not violate any rules of the jail; also asks for request to deny request of def for a property bond in lieu of a cash bond.  Harper notes that, generally, this jurisdiction does not grant property bonds on the premise that, if a party has equity in a property, the proper procedure is for a def to get a loan from a bank (in order to get the equity out of that property).  Harper states that the state/county has no interest in taking people's property if they violate bond; notes property may not be in the name of the defendant.  Atty. Longacre addresses the Court with the defense' request on bond - asks for the property bond, noting that the property is in def's name and has enough equity to cover the bond amount; states that def cannot get an equity bond while he is in custody; also argues that def has health issues that make it difficult for him to be in jail.

Ruling on bond:  16CF42 - Court notes additional criminal basis stated in the complaint filed by the AG; notes concerns re alleged threats; refers to bond statute re factors of consideration.  Court sets bond at $50,000 cash with conditions of no contact whatsoever with AB, Judge Sharp, KM, WG, TF or SPW.  Additionally, no contact with any of those individuals while in custody per 940.07.  16CF43 - Court sets bond at $10,000 cash with same conditions as the bond in 16CF42 except that there is an additional condition that def not violate any jail rules.

Court notes that prelim hearings need to be set in these two matters.  DA Harper asks that these cases be joined for prelim.  Court sets prelim in both cases for 3/16 at 1:30.

Defendant remanded to the custody of the sheriff.  Preliminary hearing scheduled for March 16, 2016 at 01:30 pm.
